trial_identification.studytitle: The impact of pharmacists-led medication monitoring programme among residents of elderly home with suboptimal blood pressure control: a randomized controlled trial
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The impact of pharmacists-led medication monitoring programme among residents of elderly home with suboptimal blood pressure control: a randomized controlled trial

interventions.interventions:
New medication monitoring system led by pharmacist in the elderly home will be the study intervention. This intervention will cover the whole 6-month study period. The pharmacist will visit the elderly home once a week to check the drug administration process and conduct medication reconciliation in elderly who recently have transition of care, i.e clinic visits and hospital visits. Medication administration record (MAR) will be checked every month. A standardized home safety checklist will be used to perform the assessment once at baseline. The checklist covers several areas including drug storage, preparation, utensils used for drug administration, drug usage records, accuracy of medications, drug administration process, and risk management. Blood pressure levels of the residents will also be reviewed. Corresponding medical officers will be informed in case there is any need for changing the residents medications. Pharmacist will document all the interventions conducted for the above medications related problems and the acceptance of the interventions. The review process of the medication records and blood pressure levels will be standardized.
Medication reconciliation will be conducted in the elderly residents who recently had a transition of care. The pharmacist will assess if there is any discrepancy in current medication, new medication and the medication listed in the discharge summary.
Elderly home staff will also be educated on the importance of the proper medication administration once a month by the visiting pharmacist. This training session will last for around 30-45 minutes with a Q&A session included.
interventions.comparator: This is alternate arm to this study, in which participants assigned to the control group will receive medications under usual medication monitoring system of the elderly home.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Changes in the systolic and diastolic blood pressure as assessed by a random-zero sphygmomanometer in the right arm with an appropriately sized cuff.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint: baseline, 3 months and 6 months from baseline

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Healthcare utilization of the elderly home residents as assessed by the data linkage to patient medical records.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint: baseline, 3 months and 6 months after baseline

secondaryOutcome.outcome: The number of interventions conducted by the pharmacist as assessed by data linkage to service records of the visitng pharmacist.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Baseline, 3 months and 6 months after baseline

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Acceptance to the interventions by the elderly home staff as assessed by a survey, in which items will be measured using a 6-point Likert scale.

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: 1. Residents not capable to communivate and comprehend Chinese; 2. The presence of disorders rendering the patient not capable to participate in this programme (e.g. schizophrenia)

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This study aims to assess the impact of the pharmacist-led medication monitoring system in the elderly home on optimizing drug therapy among elderly home residents with a known history of hypertension.
